title: Why has Riot removed a lot of RNG, except for crit?
body:
Not a discussion on whether or not crit is OP (because it obviously is and only trolling adcs would argue otherwise), but rather a discussion on why they chose to leave this in the game when they have removed other random things?

Some things were: 
-Biggest one was dodge chance of course. The removal of dodge removed a huge RNG factor in the game and made it more stable and reliable. 
-Madreds was another one; removing the chance of a proc and putting a flat, consistent amount of extra damage on it was more reliable in the jungle for consistent clear speeds as well as not accidently stealing blue buff because you got a proc while giving it to your mid laner.
-Phage was changed so there was no chance of slow, instead it gave a movespeed buff to the user on a consistent basis.
-Frozen Mallet was given a consistent, non-RNG related slow.
-Master Yi chance of extra 400 damage on Q to minions was changed to a consistent damage to minions.

Crit is worked into multiple champions in different ways, Adc's rely on it, and giving a straight up constant boost to champion attack damage is NOT a solution. Adc's are strong enough as it is, and now you want to buff every single one of them so they crit EVERY attack?

Solutions have been offered in a different thread, and indeed many of them are good solutions. However, crit is so deeply ingrained in not just the game but the minds of the players that removing it is a ridiculous amount of work. Morello commented on crit close to a year ago, and has said multiple times it's not good and they're working on it.

A year ago.

And they're still taking suggestions from the community on how to replace it.

This isn't a walk in the park, and it's not gonna happen over night.

To remove crit without affecting balance in any way is probably not even possible, let alone easy.

>Adc's are strong enough as it is, and now you want to buff every single one of them so they crit EVERY attack?

It's not a buff. It's a normalization. DPS would be exactly the same. The only thing that would lower is variability, and variability screws you just as often as it helps. To make this clear: say that I had 100 damage and 50% crit chance. Over 2 attacks, I would expect to crit once for 200 damage, meaning that I would do 100+200=300 damage. However, I could also crit twice or never, giving me 400 or 200 damage. With a %increase system, 100 damage and 50% crit would give me 150 damage for autoattacks, so I'd always do 300 damage 

So, it's not critting every attack. It's getting a % of a crit every attack, and never getting a full crit. Mathematically, this would lead to the exact same expected dps.

What do you think specifically would be a balance problem? I've thought about this, and I don't see any area where crit derandomization would be a major problem, given that dps would always be exactly the same.

>Solutions have been offered in a different thread, and indeed many of them are good solutions.

Most solutions offer new mechanics. This one doesn't. It's just the exact same damage without any randomization, leading to the same dps. It takes much less effort than putting in a totally new mechanic.

>Morello commented on crit close to a year ago, and has said multiple times it's not good and they're working on it.

They talked about it 6-8 months ago. The only major problem they had with removing crit was that they felt it created "memorable moments". Balance concerns were not brought up as a major obstacle. That goes along with that "the minds of the players" thing you brought up earlier. Derandomization is meant to preserve the same gameplay and balance, not necessarily the same feel. Critting once every 10 hits for double damage can be seen as more fun than hitting for 110% damage every time. I personally think the frustrating aspects of crit outweigh this though, which is why I still think a derandomized system is preferable.

People play based on the expected values, and mathematically, the points of major variation from the expected values are by far the exceptions. It's a rare outcome. Additionaly, no one plays around the extremely small possibilities. I don't start a fight with an IE knowing I can only win if I crit 8 times in a row. Second... no you can't. Not in League at least. League doesn't actually use RNG. It uses pRNG (psuedo RNG). This is a system used to decrease variability in random number generation. The way it works is by increasing the chance of an event every time the event does not happen. For League, this means that if I have 50% crit chance, my first hit may actually have 30% crit chance, then my second will have 40%, then 50%, and so on (the actual algorithm is a lot more complex, but you get the idea). Getting a crit lowers it back to the initial chance. Multiple crits in a row lower the chance even further (in some pRNG systems) After a point, the odds of not getting a crit or getting a streak are mathematically insignificiant. Your always crit or no crit event is so improbable that it probably hasn't happened even once in the entire time the game has been out. So, we aren't even shifting from true RNG to a normalized system, so we aren't even getting as big a variance decrease as it would initially appear.

Variance is not impactful on balance because it is just as likely to screw someone as it is to help them, and it can't be predicted, meaning the only thing anyone plays around is the expected result. The doublelift clip you linked is a good example of this (or would be, except that it wasn't actually a non-expected result. He didn't crit for most of his earlier hits. He just noticed the later hits more because he was about to die. Someone mathed it out on the Reddit thread back when that first showed up, and it was mathematically a pretty predictable result). Doublelift played around the expected result, and was surprised when he didn't get it. However, it is just as likely that the enemy could have had more crits, and killed him much quicker. Variance could just as easily have favored his opponent as it could have favored him. In terms of balance, something that has no systematic benefit is not actually affecting overall results. For example variance did not exist, we'd expect people to win and lose the exact same number of lanes, just without ever getting screwed or screwing someone else (which again, we expect to happen at equal rates).

The point is, he didn't play around that option, and neither his champion nor his role has any systematic benefits from the existence of variance. I'm not saying the game wouldn't change at all. >However, doing so requires not only extensive testing to ensure that damage actually IS similar, not just theoretically similar, 

This makes no sense. Damage in League is a math equation. This is just another math equation. DPS would be the same. We can state that as a fact. We could test it, but that's just plugging numbers into the game and letting the equation act out instead of plugging the same numbers into an equation and getting the same outcome.

The important question isn't whether damage is the same, but whether or not variance is a quality that systematically benefits or harms certain champions (for example, if "fishing for crits" is actually central to the way some champions lane). I don't think there is, and I've never seen a good example of anything that would actually change.

>Attack speed based champions that build high crit chance would be effected the most, as the game system stands attack speed steroids on high crit chance champions are one of the most broken features in the game, and indeed are the entire argument for removing the randomness in the first place.

I actually think that the low attack speed values are where the randomness affects the game the most, because with higher attack speed values the variance tends to normalize in most situations. Easier to normalize over 10 attacks than over 4 in the same period of time. Higher sample size and all that.

To wrap it up, of course this would all be tested. There is no reason not to test it even if we can mathematically predict an outcome. However, testing would likely be quick and easy unless we find a systematic benefit to some champion or role from variance (something I don't think we're likely to find), and it promises to be much less impactful on balance and gameplay than any other proposal made.

IE isn't hard. Right now, IE passive means that you get a 1.5% increase to dps for every point of crit instead of 1%. For example, if I have IE and 50% crit chance and 100 AD (numbers chosen for simplicity, although I can replicate this with realistic numbers and game scenarios if you would like)., I would have one attack for 100, and one for 250, for 350 damage. A derandomized system would have 100 ad, increased by (50% * 1.5 = 75%), for 175 AD, which would be 350 over two attacks.

Another example: We can do the same for 25% crit chance and 200 AD. Random: 3 attacks for 200, one for 500 = 1,100 damage. Derandomized: 200, increased by (25% * 1.5 = 37.5%) for 275 damage. 4 attacks at 275 = 1,100 damage.

We can do this for any crit damage modifier. As a rule, 1% extra crit damage is a 0.01% multiplier to the damage given by crit chance. IE gives an extra 50% damage to crits, so you multiply the crit chance by to get the crit damage.

So, as I see it, expected dps would be exactly the same with an IE with a random or derandomized system.

What i mean really has nothing to do with league in the first place, as it only applies to RNG, and not pRNG.

A true RNG doesn't weight a value.
In a true RNG scenario, number less than or equal to crit chance is crit, number greater is not, to a maximum of 100.
If every individual attack has a 30% chance of being a crit, theoretically at least, one in three should be a crit.
With RNG, 92 in a row could be crits, and 60 in a row could be normal hits.
There's no weighting, it simply picks a number, completely at random.
It could pick 25 12 times in a row and 7 other numbers below 30, or it could pick 19 completely different numbers over 30. Both are equally likely.
It just picks.
You'd be equally likely to get 300/1000 crits as 600/1000 crits or 1000/1000 crits.
There's no weighting, no rules, no reason the machine couldn't just endlessly pick the same number.
The problem with comparing RNG to real world scenarios is that RNG has only one variable ~ which number happens to randomly be generated. That's the only variable. If it's under a certain value, it's a normal hit, if it's above, it's a crit, but that has nothing to do with an RNG system, and only with the system that takes that randomly generated number and decides to do something with it.
To get close to being 1/3 hits as a crit with a system like that would be based on two things, sample size, and luck ~ both of which, in the case of RNG, can change.
If you got luckier, you might get it in 27 hits, if not, it might take 500.


The closest RNG can actually get to a real world scenario is a virtual coin toss, it either picks 1, or 2.

The 2 coin tosses have 4 **permutations** of equal probability (because each outcome of a single toss has the same probabilty).
Heads heads, heads tails, tails heads, tails tails.

Yes, it is possible to get 800 heads. It is possible to get 0 heads. It is also possible for the coin to land on its edge 1000 times in a row, though we usually ignore this possibility and say the only possible outcomes are heads and tails. 

We call the number of heads a random variable. Let's say we call it H. The possible values of H are any number from 0 to 1000. H has a probability distribution, which means we can calculate the probability of any of those outcomes. And if you calculate the probability that H = 800, you'll find out it isn't zero, it's just really, really small. 

So we can't guarantee that you won't get 800 heads from a fair coin, we just say it's very unlikely. And the probability is so small we're confident in predicting that it won't happen. Nevertheless, it is technically possible.
